Files

minijinja/
filters.rs

1//! Filter functions and abstractions.
2//!
3//! MiniJinja inherits from Jinja2 the concept of filter functions.  These are functions
4//! which are applied to values to modify them.  For example the expression `{{ 42|filter(23) }}`
5//! invokes the filter `filter` with the arguments `42` and `23`.
6//!
7//! MiniJinja comes with some built-in filters that are listed below. To create a
8//! custom filter write a function that takes at least a value, then registers it
9//! with [`add_filter`](crate::Environment::add_filter).
10//!
11//! # Using Filters
12//!
13//! Using filters in templates is possible in all places an expression is permitted.
14//! This means they are not just used for printing but also are useful for iteration
15//! or similar situations.
16//!
17//! Motivating example:
18//!
19//! ```jinja
20//! <dl>
21//! {% for key, value in config|items %}
22//!   <dt>{{ key }}
23//!   <dd><pre>{{ value|tojson }}</pre>
24//! {% endfor %}
25//! </dl>
26//! ```
27//!
28//! # Custom Filters
29//!
30//! A custom filter is just a simple function which accepts its inputs
31//! as parameters and then returns a new value.  For instance the following
32//! shows a filter which takes an input value and replaces whitespace with
33//! dashes and converts it to lowercase:
34//!
35//! ```
36//! # use minijinja::Environment;
37//! # let mut env = Environment::new();
38//! fn slugify(value: String) -> String {
39//!     value.to_lowercase().split_whitespace().collect::<Vec<_>>().join("-")
40//! }
41//!
42//! env.add_filter("slugify", slugify);
43//! ```
44//!
45//! MiniJinja will perform the necessary conversions automatically.  For more
46//! information see the [`Filter`] trait.
47//!
48//! # Accessing State
49//!
50//! In some cases it can be necessary to access the execution [`State`].  Since a borrowed
51//! state implements [`ArgType`] it's possible to add a parameter that holds the state.
52//! For instance the following filter appends the current template name to the string:
53//!
54//! ```
55//! # use minijinja::Environment;
56//! # let mut env = Environment::new();
57//! use minijinja::{Value, State};
58//!
59//! fn append_template(state: &State, value: &Value) -> String {
60//!     format!("{}-{}", value, state.name())
61//! }
62//!
63//! env.add_filter("append_template", append_template);
64//! ```
65//!
66//! # Filter configuration
67//!
68//! The recommended pattern for filters to change their behavior is to leverage global
69//! variables in the template.  For instance take a filter that performs date formatting.
70//! You might want to change the default time format format on a per-template basis
71//! without having to update every filter invocation.  In this case the recommended
72//! pattern is to reserve upper case variables and look them up in the filter:
73//!
74//! ```
75//! # use minijinja::Environment;
76//! # let mut env = Environment::new();
77//! # fn format_unix_timestamp(_: f64, _: &str) -> String { "".into() }
78//! use minijinja::State;
79//!
80//! fn timeformat(state: &State, ts: f64) -> String {
81//!     let configured_format = state.lookup("TIME_FORMAT");
82//!     let format = configured_format
83//!         .as_ref()
84//!         .and_then(|x| x.as_str())
85//!         .unwrap_or("HH:MM:SS");
86//!     format_unix_timestamp(ts, format)
87//! }
88//!
89//! env.add_filter("timeformat", timeformat);
90//! ```
91//!
92//! This then later lets a user override the default either by using
93//! [`add_global`](crate::Environment::add_global) or by passing it with the
94//! [`context!`] macro or similar.
95//!
96//! ```
97//! # use minijinja::context;
98//! # let other_variables = context!{};
99//! let ctx = context! {
100//!     TIME_FORMAT => "HH:MM",
101//!     ..other_variables
102//! };
103//! ```
104//!
105//! # Built-in Filters
106//!
107//! When the `builtins` feature is enabled a range of built-in filters are
108//! automatically added to the environment.  These are also all provided in
109//! this module.  Note though that these functions are not to be
110//! called from Rust code as their exact interface (arguments and return types)
111//! might change from one MiniJinja version to another.
112//!
113//! Some additional filters are available in the
114//! [`minijinja-contrib`](https://crates.io/crates/minijinja-contrib) crate.
115use std::sync::Arc;
116
117use crate::error::Error;
118use crate::utils::{write_escaped, SealedMarker};
119use crate::value::{ArgType, FunctionArgs, FunctionResult, Value};
120use crate::vm::State;
121use crate::{AutoEscape, Output};
122
123type FilterFunc = dyn Fn(&State, &[Value]) -> Result<Value, Error> + Sync + Send + 'static;
124
125#[derive(Clone)]
126pub(crate) struct BoxedFilter(Arc<FilterFunc>);
127
128/// A utility trait that represents filters.
129///
130/// This trait is used by the [`add_filter`](crate::Environment::add_filter) method to abstract over
131/// different types of functions that implement filters.  Filters are functions
132/// which at the very least accept the [`State`] by reference as first parameter
133/// and the value that that the filter is applied to as second.  Additionally up to
134/// 4 further parameters are supported.
135///
136/// A filter can return any of the following types:
137///
138/// * `Rv` where `Rv` implements `Into<Value>`
139/// * `Result<Rv, Error>` where `Rv` implements `Into<Value>`
140///
141/// Filters accept one mandatory parameter which is the value the filter is
142/// applied to and up to 4 extra parameters.  The extra parameters can be
143/// marked optional by using `Option<T>`.  The last argument can also use
144/// [`Rest<T>`](crate::value::Rest) to capture the remaining arguments.  All
145/// types are supported for which [`ArgType`] is implemented.
146///
147/// For a list of built-in filters see [`filters`](crate::filters).
148///
149/// # Basic Example
150///
151/// ```
152/// # use minijinja::Environment;
153/// # let mut env = Environment::new();
154/// use minijinja::State;
155///
156/// fn slugify(value: String) -> String {
157///     value.to_lowercase().split_whitespace().collect::<Vec<_>>().join("-")
158/// }
159///
160/// env.add_filter("slugify", slugify);
161/// ```
162///
163/// ```jinja
164/// {{ "Foo Bar Baz"|slugify }} -> foo-bar-baz
165/// ```
166///
167/// # Arguments and Optional Arguments
168///
169/// ```
170/// # use minijinja::Environment;
171/// # let mut env = Environment::new();
172/// fn substr(value: String, start: u32, end: Option<u32>) -> String {
173///     let end = end.unwrap_or(value.len() as _);
174///     value.get(start as usize..end as usize).unwrap_or_default().into()
175/// }
176///
177/// env.add_filter("substr", substr);
178/// ```
179///
180/// ```jinja
181/// {{ "Foo Bar Baz"|substr(4) }} -> Bar Baz
182/// {{ "Foo Bar Baz"|substr(4, 7) }} -> Bar
183/// ```
184///
185/// # Variadic
186///
187/// ```
188/// # use minijinja::Environment;
189/// # let mut env = Environment::new();
190/// use minijinja::value::Rest;
191///
192/// fn pyjoin(joiner: String, values: Rest<String>) -> String {
193///     values.join(&joiner)
194/// }
195///
196/// env.add_filter("pyjoin", pyjoin);
197/// ```
198///
199/// ```jinja
200/// {{ "|".join(1, 2, 3) }} -> 1|2|3
201/// ```
202pub trait Filter<Rv, Args>: Send + Sync + 'static {
203    /// Applies a filter to value with the given arguments.
204    ///
205    /// The value is always the first argument.
206    #[doc(hidden)]
207    fn apply_to(&self, args: Args, _: SealedMarker) -> Rv;
208}
209
210macro_rules! tuple_impls {
211    ( $( $name:ident )* ) => {
212        impl<Func, Rv, $($name),*> Filter<Rv, ($($name,)*)> for Func
213        where
214            Func: Fn($($name),*) -> Rv + Send + Sync + 'static,
215            Rv: FunctionResult,
216            $($name: for<'a> ArgType<'a>,)*
217        {
218            fn apply_to(&self, args: ($($name,)*), _: SealedMarker) -> Rv {
219                #[allow(non_snake_case)]
220                let ($($name,)*) = args;
221                (self)($($name,)*)
222            }
223        }
224    };
225}
226
227tuple_impls! {}
228tuple_impls! { A }
229tuple_impls! { A B }
230tuple_impls! { A B C }
231tuple_impls! { A B C D }
232tuple_impls! { A B C D E }
233
234impl BoxedFilter {
235    /// Creates a new boxed filter.
236    pub fn new<F, Rv, Args>(f: F) -> BoxedFilter
237    where
238        F: Filter<Rv, Args> + for<'a> Filter<Rv, <Args as FunctionArgs<'a>>::Output>,
239        Rv: FunctionResult,
240        Args: for<'a> FunctionArgs<'a>,
241    {
242        BoxedFilter(Arc::new(move |state, args| -> Result<Value, Error> {
243            f.apply_to(ok!(Args::from_values(Some(state), args)), SealedMarker)
244                .into_result()
245        }))
246    }
247
248    /// Applies the filter to a value and argument.
249    pub fn apply_to(&self, state: &State, args: &[Value]) -> Result<Value, Error> {
250        (self.0)(state, args)
251    }
252}
253
254/// Marks a value as safe.  This converts it into a string.
255///
256/// When a value is marked as safe, no further auto escaping will take place.
257pub fn safe(v: String) -> Value {
258    Value::from_safe_string(v)
259}
260
261/// Escapes a string.  By default to HTML.
262///
263/// By default this filter is also registered under the alias `e`.  Note that
264/// this filter escapes with the format that is native to the format or HTML
265/// otherwise.  This means that if the auto escape setting is set to
266/// `Json` for instance then this filter will serialize to JSON instead.
267pub fn escape(state: &State, v: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
268    if v.is_safe() {
269        return Ok(v);
270    }
271
272    // this tries to use the escaping flag of the current scope, then
273    // of the initial state and if that is also not set it falls back
274    // to HTML.
275    let auto_escape = match state.auto_escape() {
276        AutoEscape::None => match state.env().initial_auto_escape(state.name()) {
277            AutoEscape::None => AutoEscape::Html,
278            other => other,
279        },
280        other => other,
281    };
282    let mut rv = match v.as_str() {
283        Some(s) => String::with_capacity(s.len()),
284        None => String::new(),
285    };
286    let mut out = Output::with_string(&mut rv);
287    ok!(write_escaped(&mut out, auto_escape, &v));
288    Ok(Value::from_safe_string(rv))
289}
290
291#[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
292mod builtins {
293    use super::*;
294
295    use crate::error::ErrorKind;
296    use crate::value::ops::as_f64;
297    use crate::value::{Kwargs, ValueKind, ValueRepr};
298    use std::borrow::Cow;
299    use std::cmp::Ordering;
300    use std::fmt::Write;
301    use std::mem;
302
303    /// Converts a value to uppercase.
304    ///
305    /// ```jinja
306    /// <h1>{{ chapter.title|upper }}</h1>
307    /// ```
308    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
309    pub fn upper(v: Cow<'_, str>) -> String {
310        v.to_uppercase()
311    }
312
313    /// Converts a value to lowercase.
314    ///
315    /// ```jinja
316    /// <h1>{{ chapter.title|lower }}</h1>
317    /// ```
318    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
319    pub fn lower(v: Cow<'_, str>) -> String {
320        v.to_lowercase()
321    }
322
323    /// Converts a value to title case.
324    ///
325    /// ```jinja
326    /// <h1>{{ chapter.title|title }}</h1>
327    /// ```
328    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
329    pub fn title(v: Cow<'_, str>) -> String {
330        let mut rv = String::new();
331        let mut capitalize = true;
332        for c in v.chars() {
333            if c.is_ascii_punctuation() || c.is_whitespace() {
334                rv.push(c);
335                capitalize = true;
336            } else if capitalize {
337                write!(rv, "{}", c.to_uppercase()).unwrap();
338                capitalize = false;
339            } else {
340                write!(rv, "{}", c.to_lowercase()).unwrap();
341            }
342        }
343        rv
344    }
345
346    /// Convert the string with all its characters lowercased
347    /// apart from the first char which is uppercased.
348    ///
349    /// ```jinja
350    /// <h1>{{ chapter.title|capitalize }}</h1>
351    /// ```
352    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
353    pub fn capitalize(text: Cow<'_, str>) -> String {
354        let mut chars = text.chars();
355        match chars.next() {
356            None => String::new(),
357            Some(f) => f.to_uppercase().collect::<String>() + &chars.as_str().to_lowercase(),
358        }
359    }
360
361    /// Does a string replace.
362    ///
363    /// It replaces all occurrences of the first parameter with the second.
364    ///
365    /// ```jinja
366    /// {{ "Hello World"|replace("Hello", "Goodbye") }}
367    ///   -> Goodbye World
368    /// ```
369    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
370    pub fn replace(
371        _state: &State,
372        v: Cow<'_, str>,
373        from: Cow<'_, str>,
374        to: Cow<'_, str>,
375    ) -> String {
376        v.replace(&from as &str, &to as &str)
377    }
378
379    /// Returns the "length" of the value
380    ///
381    /// By default this filter is also registered under the alias `count`.
382    ///
383    /// ```jinja
384    /// <p>Search results: {{ results|length }}
385    /// ```
386    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
387    pub fn length(v: Value) -> Result<usize, Error> {
388        v.len().ok_or_else(|| {
389            Error::new(
390                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
391                format!("cannot calculate length of value of type {}", v.kind()),
392            )
393        })
394    }
395
396    fn sort_helper(a: &Value, b: &Value, case_sensitive: bool) -> Ordering {
397        if !case_sensitive {
398            if let (Some(a), Some(b)) = (a.as_str(), b.as_str()) {
399                #[cfg(feature = "unicode")]
400                {
401                    return unicase::UniCase::new(a).cmp(&unicase::UniCase::new(b));
402                }
403                #[cfg(not(feature = "unicode"))]
404                {
405                    return a.to_ascii_lowercase().cmp(&b.to_ascii_lowercase());
406                }
407            }
408        }
409        a.cmp(b)
410    }
411
412    /// Dict sorting functionality.
413    ///
414    /// This filter works like `|items` but sorts the pairs by key first.
415    ///
416    /// The filter accepts a few keyword arguments:
417    ///
418    /// * `case_sensitive`: set to `true` to make the sorting of strings case sensitive.
419    /// * `by`: set to `"value"` to sort by value. Defaults to `"key"`.
420    /// * `reverse`: set to `true` to sort in reverse.
421    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
422    pub fn dictsort(v: Value, kwargs: Kwargs) -> Result<Value, Error> {
423        if v.kind() == ValueKind::Map {
424            let mut rv = Vec::with_capacity(v.len().unwrap_or(0));
425            let iter = ok!(v.try_iter());
426            for key in iter {
427                let value = v.get_item(&key).unwrap_or(Value::UNDEFINED);
428                rv.push((key, value));
429            }
430            let by_value = match ok!(kwargs.get("by")) {
431                None | Some("key") => false,
432                Some("value") => true,
433                Some(invalid) => {
434                    return Err(Error::new(
435                        ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
436                        format!("invalid value '{}' for 'by' parameter", invalid),
437                    ))
438                }
439            };
440            let case_sensitive = ok!(kwargs.get::<Option<bool>>("case_sensitive")).unwrap_or(false);
441            rv.sort_by(|a, b| {
442                let (a, b) = if by_value { (&a.1, &b.1) } else { (&a.0, &b.0) };
443                sort_helper(a, b, case_sensitive)
444            });
445            if let Some(true) = ok!(kwargs.get("reverse")) {
446                rv.reverse();
447            }
448            ok!(kwargs.assert_all_used());
449            Ok(Value::from(
450                rv.into_iter()
451                    .map(|(k, v)| Value::from(vec![k, v]))
452                    .collect::<Vec<_>>(),
453            ))
454        } else {
455            Err(Error::new(
456                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
457                "cannot convert value into pair list",
458            ))
459        }
460    }
461
462    /// Returns a list of pairs (items) from a mapping.
463    ///
464    /// This can be used to iterate over keys and values of a mapping
465    /// at once.  Note that this will use the original order of the map
466    /// which is typically arbitrary unless the `preserve_order` feature
467    /// is used in which case the original order of the map is retained.
468    /// It's generally better to use `|dictsort` which sorts the map by
469    /// key before iterating.
470    ///
471    /// ```jinja
472    /// <dl>
473    /// {% for key, value in my_dict|items %}
474    ///   <dt>{{ key }}
475    ///   <dd>{{ value }}
476    /// {% endfor %}
477    /// </dl>
478    /// ```
479    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
480    pub fn items(v: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
481        if v.kind() == ValueKind::Map {
482            let mut rv = Vec::with_capacity(v.len().unwrap_or(0));
483            let iter = ok!(v.try_iter());
484            for key in iter {
485                let value = v.get_item(&key).unwrap_or(Value::UNDEFINED);
486                rv.push(Value::from(vec![key, value]));
487            }
488            Ok(Value::from(rv))
489        } else {
490            Err(Error::new(
491                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
492                "cannot convert value into pair list",
493            ))
494        }
495    }
496
497    /// Reverses an iterable or string
498    ///
499    /// ```jinja
500    /// {% for user in users|reverse %}
501    ///   <li>{{ user.name }}
502    /// {% endfor %}
503    /// ```
504    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
505    pub fn reverse(v: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
506        v.reverse()
507    }
508
509    /// Trims a value
510    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
511    pub fn trim(s: Cow<'_, str>, chars: Option<Cow<'_, str>>) -> String {
512        match chars {
513            Some(chars) => {
514                let chars = chars.chars().collect::<Vec<_>>();
515                s.trim_matches(&chars[..]).to_string()
516            }
517            None => s.trim().to_string(),
518        }
519    }
520
521    /// Joins a sequence by a character
522    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
523    pub fn join(val: Value, joiner: Option<Cow<'_, str>>) -> Result<String, Error> {
524        if val.is_undefined() || val.is_none() {
525            return Ok(String::new());
526        }
527
528        let joiner = joiner.as_ref().unwrap_or(&Cow::Borrowed(""));
529
530        if let Some(s) = val.as_str() {
531            let mut rv = String::new();
532            for c in s.chars() {
533                if !rv.is_empty() {
534                    rv.push_str(joiner);
535                }
536                rv.push(c);
537            }
538            Ok(rv)
539        } else if let Some(iter) = val.as_object().and_then(|x| x.try_iter()) {
540            let mut rv = String::new();
541            for item in iter {
542                if !rv.is_empty() {
543                    rv.push_str(joiner);
544                }
545                if let Some(s) = item.as_str() {
546                    rv.push_str(s);
547                } else {
548                    write!(rv, "{item}").ok();
549                }
550            }
551            Ok(rv)
552        } else {
553            Err(Error::new(
554                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
555                format!("cannot join value of type {}", val.kind()),
556            ))
557        }
558    }
559
560    /// If the value is undefined it will return the passed default value,
561    /// otherwise the value of the variable:
562    ///
563    /// ```jinja
564    /// <p>{{ my_variable|default("my_variable was not defined") }}</p>
565    /// ```
566    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
567    pub fn default(value: Value, other: Option<Value>) -> Value {
568        if value.is_undefined() {
569            other.unwrap_or_else(|| Value::from(""))
570        } else {
571            value
572        }
573    }
574
575    /// Returns the absolute value of a number.
576    ///
577    /// ```jinja
578    /// |a - b| = {{ (a - b)|abs }}
579    ///   -> |2 - 4| = 2
580    /// ```
581    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
582    pub fn abs(value: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
583        match value.0 {
584            ValueRepr::U64(_) | ValueRepr::U128(_) => Ok(value),
585            ValueRepr::I64(x) => match x.checked_abs() {
586                Some(rv) => Ok(Value::from(rv)),
587                None => Ok(Value::from((x as i128).abs())), // this cannot overflow
588            },
589            ValueRepr::I128(x) => {
590                x.0.checked_abs()
591                    .map(Value::from)
592                    .ok_or_else(|| Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "overflow on abs"))
593            }
594            ValueRepr::F64(x) => Ok(Value::from(x.abs())),
595            _ => Err(Error::new(
596                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
597                "cannot get absolute value",
598            )),
599        }
600    }
601
602    /// Converts a value into an integer.
603    ///
604    /// ```jinja
605    /// {{ "42"|int == 42 }} -> true
606    /// ```
607    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
608    pub fn int(value: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
609        match &value.0 {
610            ValueRepr::Undefined | ValueRepr::None => Ok(Value::from(0)),
611            ValueRepr::Bool(x) => Ok(Value::from(*x as u64)),
612            ValueRepr::U64(_) | ValueRepr::I64(_) | ValueRepr::U128(_) | ValueRepr::I128(_) => {
613                Ok(value)
614            }
615            ValueRepr::F64(v) => {
616                let x = *v as i128;
617                if x as f64 == *v {
618                    Ok(Value::from(x))
619                } else {
620                    Err(Error::new(
621                        ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
622                        format!("cannot convert float {} to integer", v),
623                    ))
624                }
625            }
626            ValueRepr::String(..) | ValueRepr::SmallStr(_) => value
627                .as_str()
628                .unwrap()
629                .parse::<i128>()
630                .map(Value::from)
631                .map_err(|err| Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, err.to_string())),
632            ValueRepr::Bytes(_) | ValueRepr::Object(_) => Err(Error::new(
633                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
634                format!("cannot convert {} to integer", value.kind()),
635            )),
636            ValueRepr::Invalid(_) => value.validate(),
637        }
638    }
639
640    /// Converts a value into a float.
641    ///
642    /// ```jinja
643    /// {{ "42.5"|float == 42.5 }} -> true
644    /// ```
645    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
646    pub fn float(value: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
647        match &value.0 {
648            ValueRepr::Undefined | ValueRepr::None => Ok(Value::from(0.0)),
649            ValueRepr::Bool(x) => Ok(Value::from(*x as u64 as f64)),
650            ValueRepr::String(..) | ValueRepr::SmallStr(_) => value
651                .as_str()
652                .unwrap()
653                .parse::<f64>()
654                .map(Value::from)
655                .map_err(|err| Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, err.to_string())),
656            ValueRepr::Invalid(_) => value.validate(),
657            _ => as_f64(&value).map(Value::from).ok_or_else(|| {
658                Error::new(
659                    ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
660                    format!("cannot convert {} to float", value.kind()),
661                )
662            }),
663        }
664    }
665
666    /// Looks up an attribute.
667    ///
668    /// In MiniJinja this is the same as the `[]` operator.  In Jinja2 there is a
669    /// small difference which is why this filter is sometimes used in Jinja2
670    /// templates.  For compatibility it's provided here as well.
671    ///
672    /// ```jinja
673    /// {{ value['key'] == value|attr('key') }} -> true
674    /// ```
675    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
676    pub fn attr(value: Value, key: &Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
677        value.get_item(key)
678    }
679
680    /// Round the number to a given precision.
681    ///
682    /// Round the number to a given precision. The first parameter specifies the
683    /// precision (default is 0).
684    ///
685    /// ```jinja
686    /// {{ 42.55|round }}
687    ///   -> 43.0
688    /// ```
689    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
690    pub fn round(value: Value, precision: Option<i32>) -> Result<Value, Error> {
691        match value.0 {
692            ValueRepr::I64(_) | ValueRepr::I128(_) | ValueRepr::U64(_) | ValueRepr::U128(_) => {
693                Ok(value)
694            }
695            ValueRepr::F64(val) => {
696                let x = 10f64.powi(precision.unwrap_or(0));
697                Ok(Value::from((x * val).round() / x))
698            }
699            _ => Err(Error::new(
700                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
701                format!("cannot round value ({})", value.kind()),
702            )),
703        }
704    }
705
706    /// Returns the first item from an iterable.
707    ///
708    /// If the list is empty `undefined` is returned.
709    ///
710    /// ```jinja
711    /// <dl>
712    ///   <dt>primary email
713    ///   <dd>{{ user.email_addresses|first|default('no user') }}
714    /// </dl>
715    /// ```
716    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
717    pub fn first(value: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
718        if let Some(s) = value.as_str() {
719            Ok(s.chars().next().map_or(Value::UNDEFINED, Value::from))
720        } else if let Some(mut iter) = value.as_object().and_then(|x| x.try_iter()) {
721            Ok(iter.next().unwrap_or(Value::UNDEFINED))
722        } else {
723            Err(Error::new(
724                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
725                "cannot get first item from value",
726            ))
727        }
728    }
729
730    /// Returns the last item from an iterable.
731    ///
732    /// If the list is empty `undefined` is returned.
733    ///
734    /// ```jinja
735    /// <h2>Most Recent Update</h2>
736    /// {% with update = updates|last %}
737    ///   <dl>
738    ///     <dt>Location
739    ///     <dd>{{ update.location }}
740    ///     <dt>Status
741    ///     <dd>{{ update.status }}
742    ///   </dl>
743    /// {% endwith %}
744    /// ```
745    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
746    pub fn last(value: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
747        if let Some(s) = value.as_str() {
748            Ok(s.chars().next_back().map_or(Value::UNDEFINED, Value::from))
749        } else if matches!(value.kind(), ValueKind::Seq | ValueKind::Iterable) {
750            let rev = ok!(value.reverse());
751            let mut iter = ok!(rev.try_iter());
752            Ok(iter.next().unwrap_or_default())
753        } else {
754            Err(Error::new(
755                ErrorKind::InvalidOperation,
756                "cannot get last item from value",
757            ))
758        }
759    }
760
761    /// Returns the smallest item from an iterable.
762    ///
763    /// ```jinja
764    /// {{ [1, 2, 3, 4]|min }} -> 1
765    /// ```
766    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
767    pub fn min(state: &State, value: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
768        let iter = ok!(state.undefined_behavior().try_iter(value).map_err(|err| {
769            Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "cannot convert value to list").with_source(err)
770        }));
771        Ok(iter.min().unwrap_or(Value::UNDEFINED))
772    }
773
774    /// Returns the largest item from an iterable.
775    ///
776    /// ```jinja
777    /// {{ [1, 2, 3, 4]|max }} -> 4
778    /// ```
779    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
780    pub fn max(state: &State, value: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
781        let iter = ok!(state.undefined_behavior().try_iter(value).map_err(|err| {
782            Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "cannot convert value to list").with_source(err)
783        }));
784        Ok(iter.max().unwrap_or(Value::UNDEFINED))
785    }
786
787    /// Returns the sorted version of the given list.
788    ///
789    /// The filter accepts a few keyword arguments:
790    ///
791    /// * `case_sensitive`: set to `true` to make the sorting of strings case sensitive.
792    /// * `attribute`: can be set to an attribute or dotted path to sort by that attribute
793    /// * `reverse`: set to `true` to sort in reverse.
794    ///
795    /// ```jinja
796    /// {{ [1, 3, 2, 4]|sort }} -> [4, 3, 2, 1]
797    /// {{ [1, 3, 2, 4]|sort(reverse=true) }} -> [1, 2, 3, 4]
798    /// # Sort users by age attribute in descending order.
799    /// {{ users|sort(attribute="age") }}
800    /// # Sort users by age attribute in ascending order.
801    /// {{ users|sort(attribute="age", reverse=true) }}
802    /// ```
803    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
804    pub fn sort(state: &State, value: Value, kwargs: Kwargs) -> Result<Value, Error> {
805        let mut items = ok!(state.undefined_behavior().try_iter(value).map_err(|err| {
806            Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "cannot convert value to list").with_source(err)
807        }))
808        .collect::<Vec<_>>();
809        let case_sensitive = ok!(kwargs.get::<Option<bool>>("case_sensitive")).unwrap_or(false);
810        if let Some(attr) = ok!(kwargs.get::<Option<&str>>("attribute")) {
811            items.sort_by(|a, b| match (a.get_path(attr), b.get_path(attr)) {
812                (Ok(a), Ok(b)) => sort_helper(&a, &b, case_sensitive),
813                _ => Ordering::Equal,
814            });
815        } else {
816            items.sort_by(|a, b| sort_helper(a, b, case_sensitive))
817        }
818        if let Some(true) = ok!(kwargs.get("reverse")) {
819            items.reverse();
820        }
821        ok!(kwargs.assert_all_used());
822        Ok(Value::from(items))
823    }
824
825    /// Converts the input value into a list.
826    ///
827    /// If the value is already a list, then it's returned unchanged.
828    /// Applied to a map this returns the list of keys, applied to a
829    /// string this returns the characters.  If the value is undefined
830    /// an empty list is returned.
831    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
832    pub fn list(state: &State, value: Value) -> Result<Value, Error> {
833        let iter = ok!(state.undefined_behavior().try_iter(value).map_err(|err| {
834            Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "cannot convert value to list").with_source(err)
835        }));
836        Ok(Value::from(iter.collect::<Vec<_>>()))
837    }
838
839    /// Converts the value into a boolean value.
840    ///
841    /// This behaves the same as the if statement does with regards to
842    /// handling of boolean values.
843    ///
844    /// ```jinja
845    /// {{ 42|bool }} -> true
846    /// ```
847    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
848    pub fn bool(value: Value) -> bool {
849        value.is_true()
850    }
851
852    /// Slice an iterable and return a list of lists containing
853    /// those items.
854    ///
855    /// Useful if you want to create a div containing three ul tags that
856    /// represent columns:
857    ///
858    /// ```jinja
859    /// <div class="columnwrapper">
860    /// {% for column in items|slice(3) %}
861    ///   <ul class="column-{{ loop.index }}">
862    ///   {% for item in column %}
863    ///     <li>{{ item }}</li>
864    ///   {% endfor %}
865    ///   </ul>
866    /// {% endfor %}
867    /// </div>
868    /// ```
869    ///
870    /// If you pass it a second argument it’s used to fill missing values on the
871    /// last iteration.
872    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
873    pub fn slice(
874        state: &State,
875        value: Value,
876        count: usize,
877        fill_with: Option<Value>,
878    ) -> Result<Value, Error> {
879        if count == 0 {
880            return Err(Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "count cannot be 0"));
881        }
882        let items = ok!(state.undefined_behavior().try_iter(value)).collect::<Vec<_>>();
883        let len = items.len();
884        let items_per_slice = len / count;
885        let slices_with_extra = len % count;
886        let mut offset = 0;
887        let mut rv = Vec::with_capacity(count);
888
889        for slice in 0..count {
890            let start = offset + slice * items_per_slice;
891            if slice < slices_with_extra {
892                offset += 1;
893            }
894            let end = offset + (slice + 1) * items_per_slice;
895            let tmp = &items[start..end];
896
897            if let Some(ref filler) = fill_with {
898                if slice >= slices_with_extra {
899                    let mut tmp = tmp.to_vec();
900                    tmp.push(filler.clone());
901                    rv.push(Value::from(tmp));
902                    continue;
903                }
904            }
905
906            rv.push(Value::from(tmp.to_vec()));
907        }
908
909        Ok(Value::from(rv))
910    }
911
912    /// Batch items.
913    ///
914    /// This filter works pretty much like `slice` just the other way round. It
915    /// returns a list of lists with the given number of items. If you provide a
916    /// second parameter this is used to fill up missing items.
917    ///
918    /// ```jinja
919    /// <table>
920    ///   {% for row in items|batch(3, '&nbsp;') %}
921    ///   <tr>
922    ///   {% for column in row %}
923    ///     <td>{{ column }}</td>
924    ///   {% endfor %}
925    ///   </tr>
926    ///   {% endfor %}
927    /// </table>
928    /// ```
929    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
930    pub fn batch(
931        state: &State,
932        value: Value,
933        count: usize,
934        fill_with: Option<Value>,
935    ) -> Result<Value, Error> {
936        if count == 0 {
937            return Err(Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "count cannot be 0"));
938        }
939        let mut rv = Vec::with_capacity(value.len().unwrap_or(0) / count);
940        let mut tmp = Vec::with_capacity(count);
941
942        for item in ok!(state.undefined_behavior().try_iter(value)) {
943            if tmp.len() == count {
944                rv.push(Value::from(mem::replace(
945                    &mut tmp,
946                    Vec::with_capacity(count),
947                )));
948            }
949            tmp.push(item);
950        }
951
952        if !tmp.is_empty() {
953            if let Some(filler) = fill_with {
954                for _ in 0..count - tmp.len() {
955                    tmp.push(filler.clone());
956                }
957            }
958            rv.push(Value::from(tmp));
959        }
960
961        Ok(Value::from(rv))
962    }
963
964    /// Dumps a value to JSON.
965    ///
966    /// This filter is only available if the `json` feature is enabled.  The resulting
967    /// value is safe to use in HTML as well as it will not contain any special HTML
968    /// characters.  The optional parameter to the filter can be set to `true` to enable
969    /// pretty printing.  Not that the `"` character is left unchanged as it's the
970    /// JSON string delimiter.  If you want to pass JSON serialized this way into an
971    /// HTTP attribute use single quoted HTML attributes:
972    ///
973    /// ```jinja
974    /// <script>
975    ///   const GLOBAL_CONFIG = {{ global_config|tojson }};
976    /// </script>
977    /// <a href="#" data-info='{{ json_object|tojson }}'>...</a>
978    /// ```
979    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(all(feature = "builtins", feature = "json"))))]
980    #[cfg(feature = "json")]
981    pub fn tojson(value: Value, pretty: Option<bool>) -> Result<Value, Error> {
982        if pretty.unwrap_or(false) {
983            serde_json::to_string_pretty(&value)
984        } else {
985            serde_json::to_string(&value)
986        }
987        .map_err(|err| {
988            Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "cannot serialize to JSON").with_source(err)
989        })
990        .map(|s| {
991            // When this filter is used the return value is safe for both HTML and JSON
992            let mut rv = String::with_capacity(s.len());
993            for c in s.chars() {
994                match c {
995                    '<' => rv.push_str("\\u003c"),
996                    '>' => rv.push_str("\\u003e"),
997                    '&' => rv.push_str("\\u0026"),
998                    '\'' => rv.push_str("\\u0027"),
999                    _ => rv.push(c),
1000                }
1001            }
1002            Value::from_safe_string(rv)
1003        })
1004    }
1005
1006    /// Indents Value with spaces
1007    ///
1008    /// The first optional parameter to the filter can be set to `true` to
1009    /// indent the first line. The parameter defaults to false.
1010    /// the second optional parameter to the filter can be set to `true`
1011    /// to indent blank lines. The parameter defaults to false.
1012    /// This filter is useful, if you want to template yaml-files
1013    ///
1014    /// ```jinja
1015    /// example:
1016    ///   config:
1017    /// {{ global_conifg|indent(2) }}          # does not indent first line
1018    /// {{ global_config|indent(2,true) }}     # indent whole Value with two spaces
1019    /// {{ global_config|indent(2,true,true)}} # indent whole Value and all blank lines
1020    /// ```
1021    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(all(feature = "builtins"))))]
1022    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1023    pub fn indent(
1024        mut value: String,
1025        width: usize,
1026        indent_first_line: Option<bool>,
1027        indent_blank_lines: Option<bool>,
1028    ) -> String {
1029        fn strip_trailing_newline(input: &mut String) {
1030            if input.ends_with('\n') {
1031                input.truncate(input.len() - 1);
1032            }
1033            if input.ends_with('\r') {
1034                input.truncate(input.len() - 1);
1035            }
1036        }
1037
1038        strip_trailing_newline(&mut value);
1039        let indent_with = " ".repeat(width);
1040        let mut output = String::new();
1041        let mut iterator = value.split('\n');
1042        if !indent_first_line.unwrap_or(false) {
1043            output.push_str(iterator.next().unwrap());
1044            output.push('\n');
1045        }
1046        for line in iterator {
1047            if line.is_empty() {
1048                if indent_blank_lines.unwrap_or(false) {
1049                    output.push_str(&indent_with);
1050                }
1051            } else {
1052                write!(output, "{}{}", indent_with, line).ok();
1053            }
1054            output.push('\n');
1055        }
1056        strip_trailing_newline(&mut output);
1057        output
1058    }
1059
1060    /// URL encodes a value.
1061    ///
1062    /// If given a map it encodes the parameters into a query set, otherwise it
1063    /// encodes the stringified value.  If the value is none or undefined, an
1064    /// empty string is returned.
1065    ///
1066    /// ```jinja
1067    /// <a href="/search?{{ {"q": "my search", "lang": "fr"}|urlencode }}">Search</a>
1068    /// ```
1069    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(all(feature = "builtins", feature = "urlencode"))))]
1070    #[cfg(feature = "urlencode")]
1071    pub fn urlencode(value: Value) -> Result<String, Error> {
1072        const SET: &percent_encoding::AsciiSet = &percent_encoding::NON_ALPHANUMERIC
1073            .remove(b'/')
1074            .remove(b'.')
1075            .remove(b'-')
1076            .remove(b'_')
1077            .add(b' ');
1078
1079        if value.kind() == ValueKind::Map {
1080            let mut rv = String::new();
1081            for k in ok!(value.try_iter()) {
1082                let v = ok!(value.get_item(&k));
1083                if v.is_none() || v.is_undefined() {
1084                    continue;
1085                }
1086                if !rv.is_empty() {
1087                    rv.push('&');
1088                }
1089                write!(
1090                    rv,
1091                    "{}={}",
1092                    percent_encoding::utf8_percent_encode(&k.to_string(), SET),
1093                    percent_encoding::utf8_percent_encode(&v.to_string(), SET)
1094                )
1095                .unwrap();
1096            }
1097            Ok(rv)
1098        } else {
1099            match &value.0 {
1100                ValueRepr::None | ValueRepr::Undefined => Ok("".into()),
1101                ValueRepr::Bytes(b) => Ok(percent_encoding::percent_encode(b, SET).to_string()),
1102                ValueRepr::String(..) | ValueRepr::SmallStr(_) => Ok(
1103                    percent_encoding::utf8_percent_encode(value.as_str().unwrap(), SET).to_string(),
1104                ),
1105                _ => Ok(percent_encoding::utf8_percent_encode(&value.to_string(), SET).to_string()),
1106            }
1107        }
1108    }
1109
1110    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1111    fn select_or_reject(
1112        state: &State,
1113        invert: bool,
1114        value: Value,
1115        attr: Option<Cow<'_, str>>,
1116        test_name: Option<Cow<'_, str>>,
1117        args: crate::value::Rest<Value>,
1118    ) -> Result<Vec<Value>, Error> {
1119        let mut rv = vec![];
1120        let test = if let Some(test_name) = test_name {
1121            Some(ok!(state
1122                .env
1123                .get_test(&test_name)
1124                .ok_or_else(|| Error::from(ErrorKind::UnknownTest))))
1125        } else {
1126            None
1127        };
1128        for value in ok!(state.undefined_behavior().try_iter(value)) {
1129            let test_value = if let Some(ref attr) = attr {
1130                ok!(value.get_path(attr))
1131            } else {
1132                value.clone()
1133            };
1134            let passed = if let Some(test) = test {
1135                let new_args = Some(test_value)
1136                    .into_iter()
1137                    .chain(args.0.iter().cloned())
1138                    .collect::<Vec<_>>();
1139                ok!(test.perform(state, &new_args))
1140            } else {
1141                test_value.is_true()
1142            };
1143            if passed != invert {
1144                rv.push(value);
1145            }
1146        }
1147        Ok(rv)
1148    }
1149
1150    /// Creates a new sequence of values that pass a test.
1151    ///
1152    /// Filters a sequence of objects by applying a test to each object.
1153    /// Only values that pass the test are included.
1154    ///
1155    /// If no test is specified, each object will be evaluated as a boolean.
1156    ///
1157    /// ```jinja
1158    /// {{ [1, 2, 3, 4]|select("odd") }} -> [1, 3]
1159    /// {{ [false, null, 42]|select }} -> [42]
1160    /// ```
1161    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
1162    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1163    pub fn select(
1164        state: &State,
1165        value: Value,
1166        test_name: Option<Cow<'_, str>>,
1167        args: crate::value::Rest<Value>,
1168    ) -> Result<Vec<Value>, Error> {
1169        select_or_reject(state, false, value, None, test_name, args)
1170    }
1171
1172    /// Creates a new sequence of values of which an attribute passes a test.
1173    ///
1174    /// This functions like [`select`] but it will test an attribute of the
1175    /// object itself:
1176    ///
1177    /// ```jinja
1178    /// {{ users|selectattr("is_active") }} -> all users where x.is_active is true
1179    /// {{ users|selectattr("id", "even") }} -> returns all users with an even id
1180    /// ```
1181    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
1182    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1183    pub fn selectattr(
1184        state: &State,
1185        value: Value,
1186        attr: Cow<'_, str>,
1187        test_name: Option<Cow<'_, str>>,
1188        args: crate::value::Rest<Value>,
1189    ) -> Result<Vec<Value>, Error> {
1190        select_or_reject(state, false, value, Some(attr), test_name, args)
1191    }
1192
1193    /// Creates a new sequence of values that don't pass a test.
1194    ///
1195    /// This is the inverse of [`select`].
1196    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
1197    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1198    pub fn reject(
1199        state: &State,
1200        value: Value,
1201        test_name: Option<Cow<'_, str>>,
1202        args: crate::value::Rest<Value>,
1203    ) -> Result<Vec<Value>, Error> {
1204        select_or_reject(state, true, value, None, test_name, args)
1205    }
1206
1207    /// Creates a new sequence of values of which an attribute does not pass a test.
1208    ///
1209    /// This functions like [`select`] but it will test an attribute of the
1210    /// object itself:
1211    ///
1212    /// ```jinja
1213    /// {{ users|rejectattr("is_active") }} -> all users where x.is_active is false
1214    /// {{ users|rejectattr("id", "even") }} -> returns all users with an odd id
1215    /// ```
1216    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
1217    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1218    pub fn rejectattr(
1219        state: &State,
1220        value: Value,
1221        attr: Cow<'_, str>,
1222        test_name: Option<Cow<'_, str>>,
1223        args: crate::value::Rest<Value>,
1224    ) -> Result<Vec<Value>, Error> {
1225        select_or_reject(state, true, value, Some(attr), test_name, args)
1226    }
1227
1228    /// Applies a filter to a sequence of objects or looks up an attribute.
1229    ///
1230    /// This is useful when dealing with lists of objects but you are really
1231    /// only interested in a certain value of it.
1232    ///
1233    /// The basic usage is mapping on an attribute. Given a list of users
1234    /// you can for instance quickly select the username and join on it:
1235    ///
1236    /// ```jinja
1237    /// {{ users|map(attribute='username')|join(', ') }}
1238    /// ```
1239    ///
1240    /// You can specify a `default` value to use if an object in the list does
1241    /// not have the given attribute.
1242    ///
1243    /// ```jinja
1244    /// {{ users|map(attribute="username", default="Anonymous")|join(", ") }}
1245    /// ```
1246    ///
1247    /// Alternatively you can have `map` invoke a filter by passing the name of the
1248    /// filter and the arguments afterwards. A good example would be applying a
1249    /// text conversion filter on a sequence:
1250    ///
1251    /// ```jinja
1252    /// Users on this page: {{ titles|map('lower')|join(', ') }}
1253    /// ```
1254    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
1255    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1256    pub fn map(
1257        state: &State,
1258        value: Value,
1259        args: crate::value::Rest<Value>,
1260    ) -> Result<Vec<Value>, Error> {
1261        let mut rv = Vec::with_capacity(value.len().unwrap_or(0));
1262
1263        // attribute mapping
1264        let (args, kwargs): (&[Value], Kwargs) = crate::value::from_args(&args)?;
1265
1266        if let Some(attr) = ok!(kwargs.get::<Option<Value>>("attribute")) {
1267            if !args.is_empty() {
1268                return Err(Error::from(ErrorKind::TooManyArguments));
1269            }
1270            let default = if kwargs.has("default") {
1271                ok!(kwargs.get::<Value>("default"))
1272            } else {
1273                Value::UNDEFINED
1274            };
1275            for value in ok!(state.undefined_behavior().try_iter(value)) {
1276                let sub_val = match attr.as_str() {
1277                    Some(path) => value.get_path(path),
1278                    None => value.get_item(&attr),
1279                };
1280                rv.push(match (sub_val, &default) {
1281                    (Ok(attr), _) => {
1282                        if attr.is_undefined() {
1283                            default.clone()
1284                        } else {
1285                            attr
1286                        }
1287                    }
1288                    (Err(_), default) if !default.is_undefined() => default.clone(),
1289                    (Err(err), _) => return Err(err),
1290                });
1291            }
1292            ok!(kwargs.assert_all_used());
1293            return Ok(rv);
1294        }
1295
1296        // filter mapping
1297        let filter_name = ok!(args
1298            .first()
1299            .ok_or_else(|| Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "filter name is required")));
1300        let filter_name = ok!(filter_name.as_str().ok_or_else(|| {
1301            Error::new(ErrorKind::InvalidOperation, "filter name must be a string")
1302        }));
1303
1304        let filter = ok!(state
1305            .env
1306            .get_filter(filter_name)
1307            .ok_or_else(|| Error::from(ErrorKind::UnknownFilter)));
1308        for value in ok!(state.undefined_behavior().try_iter(value)) {
1309            let new_args = Some(value.clone())
1310                .into_iter()
1311                .chain(args.iter().skip(1).cloned())
1312                .collect::<Vec<_>>();
1313            rv.push(ok!(filter.apply_to(state, &new_args)));
1314        }
1315        Ok(rv)
1316    }
1317
1318    /// Returns a list of unique items from the given iterable.
1319    ///
1320    /// ```jinja
1321    /// {{ ['foo', 'bar', 'foobar', 'foobar']|unique|list }}
1322    ///   -> ['foo', 'bar', 'foobar']
1323    /// ```
1324    ///
1325    /// The unique items are yielded in the same order as their first occurrence
1326    /// in the iterable passed to the filter.  The filter will not detect
1327    /// duplicate objects or arrays, only primitives such as strings or numbers.
1328    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
1329    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1330    pub fn unique(values: Vec<Value>) -> Value {
1331        use std::collections::BTreeSet;
1332
1333        let mut rv = Vec::new();
1334        let mut seen = BTreeSet::new();
1335
1336        for item in values {
1337            if !seen.contains(&item) {
1338                rv.push(item.clone());
1339                seen.insert(item);
1340            }
1341        }
1342
1343        Value::from(rv)
1344    }
1345
1346    /// Pretty print a variable.
1347    ///
1348    /// This is useful for debugging as it better shows what's inside an object.
1349    #[cfg_attr(docsrs, doc(cfg(feature = "builtins")))]
1350    #[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1351    pub fn pprint(value: &Value) -> String {
1352        format!("{:#?}", value)
1353    }
1354}
1355
1356#[cfg(feature = "builtins")]
1357pub use self::builtins::*;
